title: 5 GHz VS 2 GHz
content: 5 GHz higher bandwidth, more channels and less crowded than 2.4 GHz, but range lower. 2.4 GHz range higher but slower bandwidth, fewer channels and more crowded.

title: 802.11 Standards
content: 802.11 - 2.4 GHz, up to 2 Mbps. 802.11a - 5 GHz, up to 54 Mbps, small coverage, not interoperable w. 802.11b and 802.11g. 802.11b - 2.4 GHz, up to 11 Mbps, longer range than 802.11a. 802.11g - 2.4 GHz, up to 54 Mbps, backwards compatible w. 802.11b w. reduced bandwidth capacity. 802.11n - 2.4 & 5 GHz, range from 150 Mbps to 600 Mbps, up to 70m range, APs & clients need multiple antennas using MIMO technology, backwards compatible w. 802.11a/b/g devices w. limiting data rates. 802.11ac - 5 GHz, range from 450 Mbps to 1.3 Gbps using MIMO technology, backwards compatible with 802.11a/n devices. 802.11ax - 2.4 & 5 GHz, a.k.a. Wi-Fi 6 or High-Efficiency Wireless (HEW), better power efficncy., higher data rates, handle many devices. Will use 1 & 7 GHz when available.

title: 802.1X
content: Client - Supplicant, Switch - Authenticator, Authentication Server

title: AAA
content: Authentication, Authorization, Accounting.  Authentication - Usernames and passwords to verify the user's identity. Authorization - Controls what users can and cannot do on the network. Accounting - Collects and reports usage data, for auditing or billing. Uses TACAS+ and RADIUS to authenticate users on a central db.

title: Access Internet
content: Any address with the 10 in the first octet (e.g. 10.0.10.0) is private IPv4 and need to use Network Address Translation (NAT) to convert private IPv4 address to internet-routable IPv4 addresses.

title: Access port
content: A switch port that sends and expects traffic with no VLAN tag. Only for 1 vlan.port send/expects to receive tagged traffic.

title: Advantage of Cisco Router as relay agent
content: Provides relay services for multiple UDP services, e.g. Port 37 Times, Port 53 DNS, etc.

title: Alleviate Network Congestion
content: Fast port speeds - more data transfer per second, but more expensive; Fast internal switching - fast internal bus or shared memory; Large frame buffers - Store more frames instead of drop them, good for duplex mismatch. High port density - more ports, local traffic, less switches needed, less collisions.

title: AP Broadcast Frame
content: AP may regularly broadcast beacons. Probing, authentication and association frames are used only during association/reassociation process.

title: AP Discovery
content: A wireless NIC will send probe requests and receive broadcast beacon frames to discover an AP.

title: AP Modes
content: Passive - AP periodically sends broadcast beacon frames containing SSID, supported standards, security settings. Active - Hidden and clients need to know the name of the SSID. Client sends a probe request.

title: Auto-MDIX
content: Auto configures the port to allow device connections to use either straight-through or crossover cable. Turn on MDIX (interface config): auto mdix. Check MDIX: show controllers ethernet-controller <interface> phy

title: Before creating WLAN
content: Create a new VLAN interface. Each WLAN on Cisco 3500 WLC needs its own VLAN interface.

title: Best Practice - CDP & LLDP
content: Disable both protocols on interfaces where they are not required.

title: Best Practice - Home WAP
content: Wireless network password, AP password, SSID

title: Blocked ports
content: Not root nor designated port so, blocked.

title: Boot Sequence
content: Power-on self-test (POST) > Boot Loader > CPU init. > Flash memory init. > BOOT envr. varbl. locates IOS, IOS takes over.

title: BPDU
content: Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs) share info about themselves and their connections and are used to elect the root port.

title: Bridge ID (BID) Components
content: REDIRECT,Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDU)

title: Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDU)
content: Bridge Priority (4 bits), Extended System ID (12 bits), MAC Address (48 bits). See Root Bridge Election

title: Broadcast Domain
content: Where broadcast frames will reach. L2 switches, hubs and bridges extend the broadcast domain. Routers divide domains since they block broadcasts. Link between routers counts as broadcast domain.

title: Broadcast Storm
content: Abnormally high number of broadcasts overwhelming the network during a specific amount of time.

title: CAPWAP
content: IEEE standard procotol, provides encapsulation & forwarding of wireless user traffic btwn AP and WLC.

title: Channel
content: Adjusting channels is to avoid interference from nearby wireless devices. 1, 6 and 11 are good because they are 5 channels apart, minimising interference with other channels. Channel range is 1-11.

title: Check IP address that is assigned to MAC address
content: show ip dhcp binding (See show ip dhcp binding for more info)

title: Collision Domain
content: Only when half duplex is used. Collision happens on half duplex side. Hub increases collision domain, while switches, routers and bridges divide collision domains. To alleviate network congestion due to collisions, use a high port density switch (see Alleviate Network Congestion)

title: Configure SSH
content: 1 - Verify SSH support by using show ip ssh. 2 - Config IP domain by using ip domain-name <domain name>. 3 - Generate RSA key pairs by using cypto key generate rsa. 4 - Config user authentication by using username <username> secret <password>. 5 - Config vty lines by going to vty config using line vty 0 15 then type transport input ssh, then login local.

title: Configuring a router as a DHCP client
content: Enter the interface to configure, then type ip address dhcp

title: Create/Configure
content: For VLAN, go to VLAN Creation. For others, check the bottom. For steps before creating WLAN, see Before creating WLAN.

title: Cut-Through Switching
content: Can do rapid frame switching and has lower latency than Store-and-Forward switching. Once the destination MAC address of the frame has been looked up, forwarding decisions can be made. However due to no FCS check, invalid frames may be forwarded.

title: Designated Port When There is No Root Port
content: Leaves segments between two switches where both switches is not the root bridge. Theport on the switch with the least-cost path to the root bridge is the designated port.

title: Designated Port
content: When There is a Root Port If one end of a segment is a root port, then the other end is a designated port.

title: Designated Ports on Root Bridge
content: All ports on the root bridge are designated ports. This is because the root bridge has the lowest cost to itself.

title: DHCP Client Boot Up
content: A DHCP enabled client PC will send two broadcast messages - DHCPDISCOVER and DHCPREQUEST (see DHCPv4 Operation)

title: DHCP message types
content: DHCPACK - the DHCP server confirming that the address lease has been accepted. DHCPREQUEST - The client accepting the IP address provided by the DHCP server. DHCPDISCOVER - Client initiating message to find a DHCP server. DHCPOFFER - DHCP responding to the initial request by a client.

title: DHCP Port Number
content: 67 and 68 (if there's only 1 option select 67)

title: DHCPv4 Operation
content: Client sends Discover broadcast to find a DHCP server (DHCPDISCOVER) > Server responds init. request and sends Offer (DHCPOFFER) > Client accepts and sends Request (DHCPREQUEST) > Server confirms lease and sends DHCP Acknowledgement (DHCPACK)

title: DHCPv4 Relay
content: In the interface to the network, type ip helper-address <ip address of DHCP server>. Verify using show ip interface.

title: DHCPv6 Relay
content: In the interface to the network, type ipv6 dhcp relay destination ipv6-address [interface]. To verify, type show ipv6 dhcp interface.

title: DHCPv6 Server Types
content: Stateless - Enabled in RA messages with the ipv6 nd other-config-flag command. Clients send only DHCPv6 INFORMATION REQUEST msgs. Enabled on client using ipv6 address autoconfig command.

title: DHCPv6 Server Types
content: Stateful - M flag is 1 in RA msgs, uses address command to create pool of addresses, enabled on client using ipv6 address dhcp

title: DHCP Starvation Attack
content: Legitimate users will not be able to get valid IP addresses, Layer 2 attack.

title: Disable DTP
content: On links where trunking is not intended and when a Cisco switch is connected to a non-Cisco switch. See nonegotiate.

title: DTP (Dynamic Trunking Protocol)
content: Only on Cisco switches, used to auto negotiate trunking with another device. Links dynamically attempt trunking. Do not use for non-Cisco switches.

title: DTP modes
content: Dynamic desirable: Actively attempts to convert link to trunk; Dynamic auto: Waits for neighbour to initiate trunking;

title: Duplex
content: If one side is full & other is half, late collision occurs on the half side. To config full duplex, use duplex full in interface config.

title: Election of Designated Ports (STP)
content: All ports on the root bridge are designated ports. This is because the root bridge has the lowest cost to itself.

title: Election of Root Bridge (STP)
content: Switch with the lowest bridge ID (see Bridge ID Components) becomes root bridge. If two BIDs are the same, switch with lowest MAC address will win.

title: Election of Root Ports (STP)
content: Root port is selected based on the lowest overall cost (best path) to the root bridge. See Root Path Cost for calculating cost.

title: Enable BPDU guard
content: (config)#spanning-tree portfast bpduguard default     OR     (config-if)#spanning-tree bpduguard enable

title: Endpoint Security Solutions
content: REDIRECT,Which three Cisco products focus on endpoint security solutions

title: EtherChannel Advantages
content: No need for spanning tree recalculation when link goes down, no need to upgrade links to increase bandwidth, config can be done on the EtherChannel interface.

title: EtherChannel Load-balancing
content: Source to Destination IP, source to destination MAC.

title: EtherChannel Requirements
content: All ports need to be the same speed, duplex, VLAN info like native and allowed VLANs, and trunking mode.

title: EtherChannel Types
content: PAgP - Cisco Prop., can have max 8 active links. States - (See PAgP States). LACP - IEEE spec, can have max 8 active links, 8 standby links. States - (See LCAP States)

title: EtherChannel
content: Combines multiple physical links into a single logical link between two switches.

title: Exclude IPs from DHCP pool
content: ip dhcp excluded-address <start ip address> [end ip address range (optional)]

title: First Hop Redundancy Protocols (FHRP)
content: HSRP - Cisco prop., failover of first hop IPv4 device. (See HSRP for more info) HSRP for IPv6 - Same as HSRP but for IPv6. HSRP group has virtual MAC addr. derived from HSRP grp num and also virtual IPv6 link-local address. Periodic RAs are sent when HSRP grp is active. VRRPv2 - IPv4, one router is elected as master, rest are backups. VRRPv3 - Added support for IPv6. GLBP - Cisco Prop., allows load balancing. GLBP for IPv6 - Same thing but for IPv6. IRDP - Legacy, hosts locate routers that provide connectivity to other networks.

title: FlexConnect
content:
FlexConnect is a wireless solution for branch and remote office deployments, and allows you to control access points in a branch office from the corporate office through a WAN link, without deploying a controller in each office.

Connected mode - WLC is reachable, FlexConnect AP has CAPWAP connectivity with its WLC and can send traffic through CAPWAP tunnel.
Standalone mode - WLC in unreachable. FlexConnect AP can assume some of the WLC functions like switching client data locally and client authentication locally.

title: Frame Check Sequence (FCS)
content: The switch checks the last field of the datagram against its own FCS calculations. FCS checks for errors to ensure the frame is free of physical and data link errors.

title: Hello Message
content: Part of HSRP. Hello messages are sent every 3 seconds by default. If no hello message is received for 10 seconds, the standby router will become the active one.

title: Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP)
content: Transparent failover of first hope device; router. Used within a grp of routers for selecting active device and standby device for gateway services to a LAN.

title: HSRP
content: Cisco Proprietary Protocol. Uses active and standby routers. By default, device with the highest IPv4 addr is elected as the active router, except if a HSRP priority value is set. Priority is 100 by default, highest priority becomes active router. Active router sends Hello Messages every 3 seconds by default. Standby router becomes active one after 10 seconds if no hello message is received. No load balancing.

title: HSRP States
content: Initial - First state after config change or when interface first becomes available. Learn - Router has not determined the virtual IP addr and has not seen hello messages from the active router. It will be waiting for messages from the active router. Listen - The router knows the virtual IP addr, but the router is neither the active router nor the standby router. It listens for hello messages from those routers. Speak - The router sends periodic hello messages and actively participates in the election of the active and/or standby router. Standby - The router is a candidate to become the next active router and sends periodic hello messages. Active - The router won the election.

title: IEEE 802.1Q
content: For VLAN tag field, go to VLAN tag field. For untagged frames, go to VLAN types - native.

title: Interfaces missing in VLAN assignments
content: REDIRECT,Trunking

title: ip arp inspection validate src-mac (DAI)
content: Checks source MAC in Ethernet header against sender MAC in ARP body.

title: IP Routing
content: To allow inter-VLAN routing on a Layer 3 switch, run the ip routing command in the global config.

title: IPv4 Loopback Interface
content: A logical interface internal to the router. It is always in an UP state as long as the device is functioning properly.

title: IPv6 SLACC Default Gateway
content: link-local address of the router interface in the network.

title: LACP
content: IEEE 802.3ad (NOT Cisco Proprietary), for LACP modes, see LACP States.

title: LACP States
content: On - Force channel without LACP exchange. Active - Active negotiation state, port init. negotiations by sending LACP packets. Passive - Passive negotiation state, port receives & responds but does not initiate LACP negotiation. (On-On, Active-Active, Active-Passive)

title: Link Aggregation Protocols
content: REDIRECT,EtherChannel Types

title: Local AAA
content: Ideal for small networks where the username and password is stored in the router.

title: Lower sender port priority
content: Default port priority is 128. If 1 switch’s port were configured with a lower port priority, other switch’s port in forwarding state. The other port on S4 would be a blocking state, prevent loop.

title: Lowest overall cost to root bridge
content: REDIRECT,Root Port Election

title: MAC addr table full
content: Switch will treat all frames as unknown unicast and flood all incoming frames to all ports in the local VLAN.

title: Management Frames
content: For management frames by AP, see AP Broadcast Frames.

title: Management Interface Creation (only on the management device)
content: In global config, type interface vlan <vlan id>, then ip add <ip addr> <subnet>, no shutdown, then go back to global config,and type ip default-gateway <ip addr>

title: Min. Ethernet Frame Size
content: 64 bytes (any lower is treated as collision fragments/runt frames & discarded)

title: Mitigate VLAN attacks
content: Enable trunking manually, disable DTP, set native VLAN to unused VLAN.

title: mls qos trust cos
content: Sets the trusted state of an interface, such as voice.

title: Multiple equal-cost paths
content: When a switch has multiple equal-cost paths to the root bridge, root bridge is chosen using Lowest sender BID, Lowest sender port priority, Lowest sender port ID.

title: Native VLAN
content: REDIRECT,VLAN Types

title: no switchport access vlan <vlan no.>
content: When the command no switchport access vlan <vlan id> command is issued, the interface associated with that VLAN returns to VLAN 1.

title: no switchport trunk native vlan
content: Reset native vlan of trunk.

title: no switchport
content: Converts a port into a routed port.

title: Nonegotiate
content: Requires manual config of trunking or nontrunking. Trunk: Permanent trunking mode. switchport nonegotiate

title: QoS
content: Quality of Service. Prioritise time-sensitive traffic types like voice and video over other types like email.

title: PAgP
content: Cisco Proprietary Protocol. PAgP packets are sent between EtherChannel-capable ports to negotiate the forming of a channel. For PAgP modes, see PAgP States.

title: PAgP States
content: On - Force channel without PAgP exchanges. Desirable - Active negotiating state, initiates negotiations by sending PAgP packets. Auto - Passive negotiation state, receives & responds but does not initiate PAgP negotiation. (On-On, Desire-Desire, Desire-Auto)

title: Port Security Violation
content: shutdown (Default) - Port goes to error-disabled state, port LED off, send syslog msg, incr. violation counter. Admin must manually shut and no shut. restrict - Drop packets until no. of secure mac addr decreases below max value or max value is increased. Sends syslog msg and incr. violation counter. protect - Least secure, same as restrict except no syslog msg and no violation counter increase.
Check using show port-security <int> command.

title: Port States
content: Blocking, Listening, Learning, Forwarding, Disabled. Blocking - Only receives BPDU, no MAC addr table updates, no forwarding data frames. Listening - Receives and sends BPDU, no MAC addr table updates, no forwarding data frames. Learning - Receives and sends BPDU, MAC addr table updates, no forwarding data frames. Forwarding - Receives and sends BPDU, MAC addr table updates, forwarding data frames. Disabled - Everything no

title: RADIUS
content: Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) is a protocol and server software that provides user-based authentication for an organization. Users in a WLAN will enter username and password credentials that are verified by the RADIUS server before allowing access to the WLAN.

title: Remove only 1/all vlan from switch
content: See vlan deletion.

title: Root Bridge
content: A single switch which is used as a reference point for all path calculations. The root bridge is selected in an election process. (See Election of Root Bridge (STP))

title: Root Port Election
content: The root port is the port closest to the root bridge in terms of overall cost (best path) to the root bridge. Paths with the lowest cost become preferred, and all other redundant paths are blocked

title: Routed Ports
content: Ports on a Layer 3 switch that are used for routing. For configuration, see no switchport.

title: Router-on-a-Stick Configuration
content: Create the vlans (see VLAN creation), create mgmnt interface (see Management Interface Creation), configure access ports, configure trunking ports (see Trunking commands), then configure the subinterface & IP address (see Subinterface Configuration).

title: Router-on-a-Stick Disadvantages
content: Requires an extra router; Does not scale well beyond 50 VLANs due to network congestion.

title: Router-on-a-Stick
content: Where a router is being used to route traffic between vlans, and one connection between a router & switch serves all of the vlans. The interface on the router will have subinterfaces which connect to each vlan. To connect to a switch, you need to use trunking.

title: Security for Wireless RTR
content: Upon powering up, change default username and password of the wireless router.

title: Shared secret password
content: Used to encrypt messages between the WLC and RADIUS server.

title: show ip dhcp binding
content: Shows IPv4 addresses and assigned to hosts by DHCP server along with their MAC addresses.

title: show ip interface brief
content: Displays the IP configuration of switch ports.

title: Show SSH info
content: Use the command show ip ssh in priviledged mode.

title: show vlan brief
content: Displays VLAN assignment & membership for all switch ports.

title: shutdown/no shutdown
content: Disables/Enables a virtual or physical switch interface respectively.

title: Spanning Tree Algorithm (STA)
content: Select root bridge > Block redundant path > Loop free topography > Link failure = recalculate path.

title: Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)
content: Prevent L2 loops which can result in broadcast storms by disabling redundant paths. Can calculate best path when there is a failure. No STP = Endless loop of frames + high CPU utilization n MAC address table instability.

title: SSH (Secure Shell)
content: Pretty much the same as Telnet but SSH has encryption so more secure.

title: SSH/Telnet Configuration
content: In the vty lines, enter transport input all / transport input ssh / transport input telnet.

title: Store-and-Forward Switching
content: Two characteristics: Error checking and Automatic buffering. Error checking does a frame check sequence (FCS) after receiving the whole frame. If the frame has no errors, it Is forwarded. Otherwise, it is dropped. Automatic Buffering allows flexibility for different Ethernet speeds.

title: STP Types
content: STP - Original IEEE version, assumes 1 spanning tree regardless of VLANs. PVST+ - Cisco enhancement of STP, provides separate tree instance for each VLAN, supports PortFast, UplinkFast, BackboneFast, BPU guard & filter, root and loop guards. RSTP - Faster upgrade of STP. Rapid PVST+ - Cisco enhancement of RSTP, each separate tree insurance supports the services above in PVST+. MSTP - IEEE standard, maps multiple VLANs to same spanning tree instance. MST - Same physical and logical topology as MSTP, provides 16 instances of RSTP and combines many VLANs into the same physical and logical topology as RSTP instance. Supports services like PVST+ above.

title: Subinterface Configuration
content: In the subinterface config (e.g. interface G0/0/1.10 for vlan 10), type encapsulation dot1Q <vlan id>, then type ip add <ip addr> <subnet mask>. (Good to put description too)

title: SVI inter-vlan routing benefits
content: Faster switching of packets, and there is no need for a connection to a router.

title: Switch Boot Up Sequence
content: 1.       Switch loads and executes Power-On-Self-Test (POST)
2.      Switch loads boot loader software.
3.      Boot loader performs low-level CPU initialization.
4.      Boot loader initializes flash memory.
5.      Boot loader locates and loads default IOS image.

title: Switch Forwarding Methods
content: Store & forward: Check for errors, if err drop frame, auto buffering for duplex mismatch. Cut-through: Ignore errors, less latency.

title: Switch Mode
content: Between Switch and Router/Switch, use trunk.

title: Switch Ports
content: For when assigned VLAN is deleted, go to VLAN deletion.

title: Switch Verification commands
content:
show interfaces : disp. interface stat and config.
show startup-config: disp. current startup config.
show interfaces switchport: Display encapsulation type, voice VLAN ID, access mode VLAN, etc.
show running-config: Display current running config.
show flash: Display info about flash file sys.
show version: Display sys. hardware and software stat.
show history: disp. history of command entered.
show ip[v6] interface : disp. IP info about an interface.
show mac address-table: disp. MAC address table.

title: Switch Virtual Interface (SVI) Inter-VLAN Routing
content: An SVI needs to be created for each VLAN.

title: Switching
content: Uses CAM table which maps MAC addresses to ports (interface). When frame received, check src MAC in addr table, if not in addr table, add MAC and port to table. Else, send to port in addr table. If dest. MAC is new, bcast to all ports except ingress port. Else, send to port in addr table.

title: Switchport commands
content:
Enter switchport mode first. can be access or trunk.
Access: switchport mode access Trunk: switchport mode trunk
Allow VLANs on trunks: switchport trunk allowed vlan (NOTE: ONLY the VLANs listed will be allowed)

title: Telnet Configuration
content: REDIRECT,SSH/Telnet Configuration.

title: Telnet Port
content: TCP port 23

title: Telnet
content: Sends everything in plain text, including usernames & passwords. Use SSH instead as it's more secure.

title: Transport Input
content: Specifies which connection (SSH/Telnet/both) to allow on vty lines. To configure, go to vty lines (line vty 0-15) then type transport input <all | ssh | telnet>

title: Trunking commands
content: In Interface config, turn on trunk mode: switchport mode trunk, set native vlan (if needed): switchport trunk native vlan <vlan id>, allow vlans on the trunk: switchport trunk allowed vlan <vlan list>

title: Trunking
content: Trunk ports do not show in show vlan brief as they do not belong to a vlan. Trunk port sends/expects to receive tagged traffic.  | CFI | VID (2 bytes, 3 bits, 1 bit, 12 bits) Tag: |ethernet type(0X8100) | Pri | CFI | VID| (2 bytes, 3 bits, 1 bit, 12 bits).

title: Types of Wireless Networks
content: WPAN - Wireless Personal-Area Network, low powered transmitters, short range network, based on 802.15 standard and 2.4 GHz. WLAN - Wireless LAN, uses transmitters to cover medium sized network. Suitable for home, office and campus. Based on 802.11 standard, uses 2.4 or 5 GHz.  WMAN - Wireless Metropolitan Area Network, uses transmitters to cover a larger geographic area, suitable for cities / districts, use specific licensed frequencies. WWAN - Wireless Wide Area Networks, uses transmitters to cover an extensive geographic area, suitable for national and global comms, also use specific licensed frequencies.

title: Untagged frames
content: Use native vlan (see VLAN types - native)

title: Verification Commands
content: show running-config - Shows currently running configuration. show ip interface - Shows IP configuration of interfaces. show vlan - Shows VLAN configuration. show interfaces trunk - Shows trunk configuration, along with native VLAN.

title: Violation modes
content: REDIRECT,Port Security Violation.

title: VLAN benefits
content: Smaller bcast domains, more security as devices can only comm. in same vlan, improved network efficiency & perf., cost reduction as no need to buy switches, simple project & app mgment. Separate functions makes specialised apps easier.

title: VLAN communication
content: Devices can only communicate within the same vlan. e.g. broadcast cannot go from vlan 20 to vlan 30.

title: VLAN creation
content: In global config, enter vlan <vlan id>, then name <vlan-name>

title: VLAN deletion
content: To delete only 1 vlan, in global config, enter no vlan <vlan id>. To delete all vlans, in exec mode, run delete flash:vlan.dat. Ports won't be disabled, but they will just stop communicating with the attached devices.

title: VLAN double-tagging attack
content: A VLAN Hopping Attack where the attacker embeds a hidden 802.1Q tag inside the frame that already has an 802.1Q tag. This allows the frame to go to a VLAn that the original 802.1Q tag did not specify.
The native and user VLANs being the same makes it vulnerable to VLAN double-tagging attacks.

title: VLAN tag field
content: Type - Value for the tag protocol ID value. VLAN ID - VLAN number. User Priority - Value that supports level or service implementation. Canonical Format Identifier - Identifier that enables Token Ring frames to be carried across Ethernet links.

title: VLAN types
content: Default (vlan 1, default mgment vlan), data (separate network into groups of users or devices), management (for SSH, Telnet, HTTP(S), SNMP), native (default vlan 1, used for trunks, untagged across trunks, provide a common identifier across trunks), voice (for VoIP, delay < 150ms, priority)

title: Which two concepts is for switch ports to connect only end devices and not to another switch?
content: Edge Port, PortFast

title: Why Active Clients for IPv6 is 0
content: The state is not maintained by the DHCPv6 server under stateless mode. When the command ipv6 nd other-config-flag is set, the DHCPv6 does not maintain state information. (Stateless)

title: Why DHCPDISCOVER is broadcast
content: Client doesn't have IP address yet to send unicast messages.

title: Why DHCPREQUEST is broadcast
content: Client may have received offers from multiple servers, broadcast is to decline those offers.

title: Why ISP assigns DHCP to Wireless Router in SOHO environment
content: Easy IP address management

title: Wireless antennas
content: Omnidirectional - 360 deg coverage, ideal for home, open office area, conference room, outdoors. Directional - Focus radio signal in one direction, stronger signal strength in one direction and reduced in other directions. Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) - Multiple antennas to increase bandwidth for 802.11n/ac/ax networks, up to eight transmit and receive antennas can be used.

title: Wireless network not showing
content: Access point may be operating in active mode.

title: Wireless security modes
content: Personal - One shared password for all users. Enterprise -Users need to login with username and password, RADIUS server authenticates them.

title: Windows failed to get IPv4 address
content: Windows will automatically set the IP address to start with 168.254.

title: Which one of the following statements describes the behaviour of a switch when the MAC address/CAM table is full?
content: It treats all frames as unknown unicast and floods all incoming frames to all ports within the local VLAN.

title: Which Layer 2 attack will result in legitimate users not getting valid IP addresses?
content: DHCP Starvation

title: What mitigation plan is best for thwarting a DoS attack that is creating a MAC address table overflow?
content: Enable port security.

title: Which three Cisco products focus on endpoint security solutions? (Choose three.)
content: Web Security Appliance, Email Security Appliance, NAC Appliance.
